hotspots.label: White Egret Bird
hotspots.fact: This beautiful white bird is called an egret, and it has special body parts that help it survive in its habitat. Its long, pointed beak is perfect for catching fish in water, and its long legs help it wade through shallow ponds and streams. Different animals have different body structures that help them get food and stay safe in their homes.

vocabulary.definition: The place where an animal lives and finds food, water, and shelter.

hotspots.label: Green Frog Decoration
hotspots.fact: Frogs are amazing animals that live both on land and in water! Real frogs are important members of ecosystems because they eat insects and other small creatures, keeping the environment in balance. When a frog eats an insect, that's an example of one living thing depending on another for food.

vocabulary.definition: All the living things (plants and animals) in a place, plus the non-living things like water, soil, and rocks that they depend on.

hotspots.label: Blue-Gray Agave Plant
hotspots.fact: This spiky blue-gray plant is called an agave, and it's a living organism that grows in dry areas. Plants like this one need sunlight, water, and nutrients from soil to grow and survive, just like all living things need food and water. The thick, waxy leaves help the agave plant store water so it can survive in hot, dry climates.

vocabulary.definition: Any living thing, like a plant, animal, or insect.

hotspots.label: Green Leafy Plant
hotspots.fact: This tall green plant with long leaves is part of the garden ecosystem shown here. Plants are producers, which means they make their own food using sunlight through a process called photosynthesis. Animals in the ecosystem, like birds and insects, depend on plants for food and shelter, showing how living things are connected to each other.

vocabulary.definition: A living thing, usually a plant, that makes its own food using sunlight and energy from the sun.
